nodes.text: Conservation of money in a closed ensemble of agents implies, by statistical mechanics and maximal entropy, an exponential stationary distribution of money leading to intrinsic inequality, while nonconservative processes (state money creation, bank lending, debt) and transaction rules (additive vs multiplicative) modify this outcome

Analogy with statistical physics: conserved additive quantity plus multiplicative probability yields Boltzmann-Gibbs exponential distribution P(m) proportional to exp(-m/Tm) with Tm = total money M divided by number of agents N
Kinetic approach: a Boltzmann-type equation for money transfers with detailed-balance and time-reversal symmetry leads to exponential stationary solution regardless of microscopic transition rates

When transaction rules are multiplicative (percent transfers) or mixed, time-reversal symmetry is broken and stationary distributions deviate from pure exponential, often becoming Gamma-like with exponential tail or power-law tail for high end

Entropy maximization argument: maximal combinatorial multiplicity for conserved money under constraint of fixed total money yields exponential distribution and monotonic entropy increase (second law analogue)
Nonconservative processes (vertical flows) such as state issuance of fiat money and central bank monetization change total money M and thus alter money temperature Tm and inequality dynamics

Result from simulations and analytic reduction: starting from equal initial money, additive-transfer models evolve to broad, asymmetric distributions with accumulation near lower boundary and final exponential stationary P(m) if a lower bound m>0 is imposed

Interpretation: exponential money distribution implies many poor agents and few rich agents even when agents are statistically identical, so inequality can arise from purely statistical processes rather than intrinsic agent differences

Method reduction: for small transaction amounts, the Boltzmann equation reduces to Fokker-Planck (or Fokker-Planck-type) equation with drift A and diffusion B; additive constants give exponential stationary solution with temperature Tm = B/A

Empirical evidence: US income data show two-class structure—majority lower class follows exponential distribution, high-income upper class follows Pareto power law—consistent with additive plus multiplicative stochastic processes

Claim about institutions: commercial banks create debt (paired liabilities and assets) that increases money-like balances among agents but does not increase net reserves; central bank purchases of government debt inject exogenous money into the system

Result on debt dynamics: allowing unrestricted debt (removing lower-bound constraint on net worth) leads to indefinite widening of net-worth distribution, continually increasing entropy and no equilibrium unless debt limits or insolvency mechanisms are imposed

Evidence and empirical claim: quantitative easing and central bank bailouts direct newly created money to financial sector, increasing income share of upper class and spiking measured inequality during asset bubbles

Claim about instability mechanisms: endogenous debt expansion, collateral price inflation, and synchronization of borrowing create credit bubbles that eventually trigger systemic crises (Minsky moments) requiring state intervention and monetization of debt

Conclusion: ultimate source of aggregate capitalist monetary profit and broad restoration of balance after crises is state-issued exogenous money and central bank actions; private-credit-created gains are often socialized losses when crises are resolved

Limitation and open problem: the paper focuses on monetary/informational layer and stylized models; coupling to physical constraints (energy, resources) and collective synchronization dynamics of debt expansion remain important open issues for econophysics
